relationships.evidence_text: I was part of a team that took a company through the certification process about a decade ago.
It's interesting just to kind of focus on how much the organization and the standards have changed in just a decade.
B-Corps today are actually required either to become a public benefit corporation or an equivalent by mending their charter.
we've spent the last decade now getting legislation passed in over 40 states and countries around the world.

relationships.target: must make decisions in alignment with stakeholders
relationships.evidence_text: to ensure that boards and managers of companies must make decisions in alignment with stakeholders.

relationships.evidence_text: Often we hear the conversation in business be about moving away from shareholder primacy to what we call a stakeholder-driven economy.
it embeds the mission, the commitment that businesses must have to make decisions to benefit those stakeholders.
the certification or the framework of B-Corp certification is set up with five stakeholders in mind.

relationships.target: employees, customers, shareholders, suppliers, and the planet

it's an open-source tool.
the certification or the framework of B-Corp certification is set up with five stakeholders in mind. That's employees, customers, shareholders as well, but also suppliers and the planet.
over 250,000 companies around the world have accessed what we call the B-Impact Assessment, the BIA, which houses these questions.
B-Corps, because they have to recertify every three years, they are continuously improving.
our standards change, our requirements also increase.
we also expect that B-Corps are improving their impact across those stakeholders.

The idea of open hiring in many ways is quite radical because it removes barriers of access to employment.
It removes the need for background checks, for credit scores, for references that commonly create barriers for many marginalized communities.
but in particular for those that are formerly incarcerated.
